cluster_relations.rel_desc: Rapid transmission of information causes or contributes to the proliferation of urban legends.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a causal factor that brings about or significantly contributes to the object event, state, or condition.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Biased training data can cause AI systems to produce discriminatory outcomes.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a causal factor that leads to the occurrence or persistence of the object outcome or state, potentially under specified conditions or with uncertainty qualifiers.
args.justification: These two relations express the same general causal predicate as the other 'causes' relations in this chunk. Normalizing their rel_cls to 'causal_effect_relation' and harmonizing the canonical_rel_desc with the majority avoids having two nearly synonymous causal classes ('causal_influence_relation' vs 'causal_effect_relation') for identical semantics.
args.remark: Standardized all 'causes' relations in this chunk to a single causal_effect_relation class and shared description.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Connects an act or pattern of discrimination to the protected attribute (e.g., race, gender) that forms the basis or target of that discrimination.
args.justification: These relations link discrimination to the protected characteristic it targets. This is better modeled as an attribution/basis relation rather than a direct causal relation. Changing rel_cls_group from 'CAUSALITY' to 'ATTRIBUTION' more accurately reflects that the protected attribute is the basis or grounds of discrimination, not a causal factor in the usual sense.
args.remark: Reclassified discrimination basis edges under the ATTRIBUTION group to distinguish them from true causal effect relations.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a causal factor that leads to the occurrence or persistence of the object outcome or state, potentially under specified conditions or with uncertainty qualifiers.
executed_decisions.justification: These two relations express the same general causal predicate as the other 'causes' relations in this chunk. Normalizing their rel_cls to 'causal_effect_relation' and harmonizing the canonical_rel_desc with the majority avoids having two nearly synonymous causal classes ('causal_influence_relation' vs 'causal_effect_relation') for identical semantics.
executed_decisions.remark: Standardized all 'causes' relations in this chunk to a single causal_effect_relation class and shared description.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Connects an act or pattern of discrimination to the protected attribute (e.g., race, gender) that forms the basis or target of that discrimination.
executed_decisions.justification: These relations link discrimination to the protected characteristic it targets. This is better modeled as an attribution/basis relation rather than a direct causal relation. Changing rel_cls_group from 'CAUSALITY' to 'ATTRIBUTION' more accurately reflects that the protected attribute is the basis or grounds of discrimination, not a causal factor in the usual sense.
executed_decisions.remark: Reclassified discrimination basis edges under the ATTRIBUTION group to distinguish them from true causal effect relations.
